feed.subtitle: UCLA website for the mathematics graduate student Jason Schuchardt.

entry.title: Extending 2-variable adjunctions to diagram categories
entry.content:
Weâ€™d like to understand the following proposition, due (as near as I can tell) to Quillen in Homotopical Algebra:

Proposition If C\calCC is a category, then the category of simplicial C\calCC-objects is enriched, tensored, and cotensored over sSet\sSetsSet.

In fact, this is a special case of the following proposition

Proposition If −⊗−:C×D→E-\otimes- : \calC\times \calD\to \calE−⊗−:C×D→E forms a 2-variable adjunction with [−,−]:Cop×E→D[-,-] : \calC^\op\times\calE \to \calD[−,−]:Cop×E→D and {−,−}:Dop×E→C\{-,-\} : \calD^\op\times \calE\to \calC{−,−}:Dop×E→C, III is a small category, and C\calCC and D\calDD are complete and cocomplete, then there is a 2-variable adjunction −⊗^−:CI×DI→EI-\widehat{\otimes} - : \calC^I \times \calD^I \to \calE^I−⊗​−:CI×DI→EI, with left and right adjoints [−,−]^\widehat{[-,-]}[−,−]​ and {−,−}^\widehat{\{-,-\}}{−,−}​ respectively, defined by the following formulae, where F:I→CF:I\to \calCF:I→C, G:I→DG:I\to\calDG:I→D, H:I→EH:I\to \calEH:I→E:

F⊗^G=I→ΔI×I→F×GC×D→⊗E,F\widehat{\otimes}G = I\toby{\Delta} I\times I \toby{F\times G} \calC\times\calD \toby{\otimes} \calE,F⊗​G=IΔ​I×IF×G​C×D⊗​E, [F,H]^=∫i∈I[I(−,i)⊗Fi,Hi],\widehat{[F,H]} = \int_{i\in I} \left[ I(-,i) \otimes Fi,Hi \right],[F,H]​=∫i∈I​[I(−,i)⊗Fi,Hi], {G,H}^=∫i∈I{I(−,i)⊗Gi,Hi}\widehat{\{G,H\}} = \int_{i\in I} \left\{ I(-,i) \otimes Gi,Hi \right\}{G,H}​=∫i∈I​{I(−,i)⊗Gi,Hi}

Proof.

The proof is a standard exercise in manipulating ends, weâ€™ll give the natural isomorphism for ⊗^\widehat{\otimes}⊗​ and [−,−]^\widehat{[-,-]}[−,−]​, since the other natural isomorphism is the symmetric.

EI(G,[F,H]^)≃∫j∈IE(Gj,∫i∈I[I(j,i)⊗Fi,Hi])≃∫i,j∈IE(Gj,[I(j,i)⊗Fi,Hi])≃∫i,j∈IE((I(j,i)⊗Fi)⊗Gj,Hi)≃∫i,j∈IE(I(j,i)⊗(Fi⊗Gj),Hi)≃∫i,j∈ISet(I(j,i),E(Fi⊗Gj,Hi))≃∫i∈IE(Fi⊗Gi,Hi)≃EI(F⊗^G,H)■\newcommand\of[1]{\left({#1}\right)} \newcommand\hattimes{\widehat{\otimes}} \newcommand\hatbrak[2]{\widehat{\left[{#1},{#2}\right]}} \newcommand\hatbrace[2]{\widehat{\left\{ {#1},{#2}\right\}}} \begin{aligned} \calE^I \of{ G, \hatbrak{F}{H} } &\simeq \int_{j\in I} \calE \of{ Gj, \int_{i\in I} [I(j,i)\otimes Fi, Hi] } \\ &\simeq \int_{i,j\in I} \calE \of{ Gj, [I(j,i)\otimes Fi, Hi] } \\ &\simeq \int_{i,j\in I} \calE \of{ \of{I(j,i)\otimes Fi}\otimes Gj, Hi } \\ &\simeq \int_{i,j\in I} \calE \of{ I(j,i)\otimes \of{Fi\otimes Gj}, Hi } \\ &\simeq \int_{i,j\in I} \Set\of{ I(j,i), \calE \of{ Fi\otimes Gj, Hi } } \\ &\simeq \int_{i\in I} \calE \of{ Fi\otimes Gi, Hi } \\ &\simeq \calE^I\of{F\hattimes G,H} \qquad \blacksquare \end{aligned}EI(G,[F,H]​)​≃∫j∈I​E(Gj,∫i∈I​[I(j,i)⊗Fi,Hi])≃∫i,j∈I​E(Gj,[I(j,i)⊗Fi,Hi])≃∫i,j∈I​E((I(j,i)⊗Fi)⊗Gj,Hi)≃∫i,j∈I​E(I(j,i)⊗(Fi⊗Gj),Hi)≃∫i,j∈I​Set(I(j,i),E(Fi⊗Gj,Hi))≃∫i∈I​E(Fi⊗Gi,Hi)≃EI(F⊗​G,H)■​

The result itself is fairly mundane to prove, but the ideas behind it and the consequences are quite interesting.

Some Consequences

Letâ€™s first observe some corollaries.

Corollary (a) If V\calVV is closed (symmetric) monoidal, complete, and cocomplete, then VI\calV^IVI is also closed (symmetric) monoidal. (b) sSet\sSetsSet is closed symmetric monoidal. (c) If C\calCC is V\calVV-enriched, tensored, and cotensored, complete and cocomplete as an ordinary category, and V\calVV is as in (a), then CI\calC^ICI is VI\calV^IVI-enriched, tensored, and cotensored. (d) If C\calCC is complete and cocomplete, then CΔop\calC^{\Delta^\op}CΔop is sSet\sSetsSet-enriched, tensored, and cotensored.

Proof.

(a) Since the multiplication on the functor category is the pointwise tensor product, itâ€™s easy to check that we get monoidal structure natural isomorphisms on the functor category.

(b) This follows from (a), since sSet=SetΔop\sSet=\Set^{\Delta^\op}sSet=SetΔop.

(c) Directly analagous to (a), since being enriched, tensored, and cotensored can be expressed as there being a tensor V×C→C\calV\times \calC \to \calCV×C→C, which has appropriate unitality and associativity isomorphisms which are compatible with those of the monoidal structure on V\calVV, and admitting the appropriate adjoints to form a 2-variable adjunction.

(d) Follows from (c) in exactly the same manner as (a). We note that the tensor product of a simplicial set K∙K_\bulletK∙​ and a simplicial object C∙C_\bulletC∙​ is given by

(K∙⊗C∙)n=Kn⊗Cn,(K_\bullet\otimes C_\bullet)_n = K_n\otimes C_n,(K∙​⊗C∙​)n​=Kn​⊗Cn​,

the hom simplicial set between simplicial objects C∙C_\bulletC∙​ and D∙D_\bulletD∙​ is given by

[Δop,C]‾(C∙,D∙)n=[Δop,C](Δn⊗C∙,D∙),\underline{[\Delta^\op,\calC]}(C_\bullet,D_\bullet)_n = [\Delta^\op,\calC](\Delta^n \otimes C_\bullet, D_\bullet),[Δop,C]​(C∙​,D∙​)n​=[Δop,C](Δn⊗C∙​,D∙​),

and the cotensor of a simplicial set K∙K_\bulletK∙​ with a simplicial object C∙C_\bulletC∙​ is given by

[K∙,C∙]n=∫m∈Δop[Δmn×Km,Cm].[K_\bullet,C_\bullet]_n = \int_{m\in \Delta^\op} [\Delta^n_m\times K_m, C_m].[K∙​,C∙​]n​=∫m∈Δop​[Δmn​×Km​,Cm​].

Some Thoughts and Observations

Firstly, we can exploit the symmetry of 2-variable adjunctions to get 2-variable adjunctions (Cop)I×EI→DI(\calC^\op)^I\times \calE^I \to \calD^I(Cop)I×EI→DI given by (F,H)↦[F−,H−](F,H)\mapsto [F-,H-](F,H)↦[F−,H−] and (Dop)I×EI→CI(\calD^\op)^I\times \calE^I\to \calC^I(Dop)I×EI→CI given by (G,H)↦{G−,H−}(G,H)\mapsto \{G-,H-\}(G,H)↦{G−,H−}. The left mapping adjoint in these adjunctions gives us 2-variable adjunctions CIop×DI→EI\calC^{I^\op}\times \calD^I\to\calE^ICIop×DI→EI and DIop×CI→EI.\calD^{I^\op}\times \calC^I\to \calE^I.DIop×CI→EI.

In particular, this should give us a simplicial enrichment on the category of cosimplicial objects.

The first functor defined is the cotensor, [K∙,C∙]n=[Kn,Cn],[K_\bullet,C_\bullet]_n=[K_n,C_n],[K∙​,C∙​]n​=[Kn​,Cn​], as described above, since it is of the form sSetop×CΔ→CΔ\sSet^\op\times \calC^\Delta\to \calC^\DeltasSetop×CΔ→CΔ. By symmetry, we can view it as a tensor for the purposes of the proposition above. When we think of [−,−]:Setop×C→C[-,-]:\Set^\op \times\calC \to \calC[−,−]:Setop×C→C as the tensor, then the right mapping adjoint is of the form Cop×C→Setop\calC^\op\times \calC\to \Set^\opCop×C→Setop, which is equivalent to C×Cop→Set.\calC\times \calC^\op\to\Set .C×Cop→Set. Thus the right mapping adjoint should be given by Cop:C×Cop→Set.\calC^\op :\calC\times\calC^\op\to \Set.Cop:C×Cop→Set. The right mapping adjoint of the cotensor of simplicial objects will thus be of the form (CΔ)op×CΔ→(Setop)Δ≃sSetop,(\calC^\Delta)^\op\times \calC^\Delta \to (\Set^\op)^\Delta \simeq \sSet^\op,(CΔ)op×CΔ→(Setop)Δ≃sSetop, and be computed by

(F,G)↦∫m∈ΔCop([Δm−,Fm],Gm),(F,G)\mapsto \int^{m\in\Delta} \calC^\op([\Delta^{-}_{m},Fm],Gm),(F,G)↦∫m∈ΔCop([Δm−​,Fm],Gm),

where the end should have become a coend, since we swapped Setop\Set^\opSetop with Set\SetSet, but itâ€™s going to need to turn back into an end for the final formula, and I canâ€™t figure out where the calculation went wrong. Then (identifying the functor with its opposite) this is of the form CΔ×(CΔ)op→sSet.\calC^\Delta\times(\calC^\Delta)^\op\to \sSet.CΔ×(CΔ)op→sSet. Note that the arguments to the right mapping functor are reversed from what we expect for the enriched hom functor. Swapping these gives the formula:

CΔ‾(F,G)n=∫m∈ΔC(Fm,[Δmn,Gm]).\underline{\calC^\Delta}(F,G)_n = \int_{m\in \Delta} \calC(Fm, [\Delta^n_m,Gm]).CΔ​(F,G)n​=∫m∈Δ​C(Fm,[Δmn​,Gm]).

As a quick check, computing

sSet(K∙,CΔ‾(F,G)∙)≃∫n∈Δop∫m∈ΔSet(Kn,C(Fm,[Δmn,Gm]))≃∫n∈Δop∫m∈ΔSet(Δnm,C(Fm,[Kn,Gm]))≃∫n∈ΔopC(Fn,[Kn,Gn])≃CΔop(F∙,[K∙,G∙]),\begin{aligned} \sSet(K_\bullet,\underline{\calC^\Delta}(F,G)_\bullet) &\simeq \int_{n\in\Delta^\op}\int_{m\in\Delta} \Set(K_n,\calC(Fm,[\Delta^n_m,Gm])) \\ &\simeq \int_{n\in\Delta^\op}\int_{m\in\Delta} \Set(\Delta^{n_m},\calC(Fm,[K_n,Gm])) \\ &\simeq \int_{n\in\Delta^\op}\calC(Fn,[K_n,Gn]) \\ &\simeq \calC^{\Delta^\op}(F_\bullet,[K_\bullet,G_\bullet]), \\ \end{aligned}sSet(K∙​,CΔ​(F,G)∙​)​≃∫n∈Δop​∫m∈Δ​Set(Kn​,C(Fm,[Δmn​,Gm]))≃∫n∈Δop​∫m∈Δ​Set(Δnm​,C(Fm,[Kn​,Gm]))≃∫n∈Δop​C(Fn,[Kn​,Gn])≃CΔop(F∙​,[K∙​,G∙​]),​

as required.

It turns out that weâ€™ve recovered the construction of the simplicial enriching on cosimplicial objects described by nnnLab here, which we obtain by regarding the category of cosimplicial objects in C\calCC as the opposite of the category of simplicial objects in Cop.\calC^\op.Cop.

We can compute the hom simplicial sets of the construction on nnnLab as well to verify this. We get

CΔ‾(F,G)n=∫m∈ΔCop([Δmn,Gm],Fm)=∫m∈ΔC(Fm,[Δmn,Gm]).\underline{\calC^\Delta}(F,G)_n = \int_{m\in\Delta}\calC^\op([\Delta^n_m,Gm],Fm)= \int_{m\in \Delta} \calC(Fm, [\Delta^n_m,Gm]).CΔ​(F,G)n​=∫m∈Δ​Cop([Δmn​,Gm],Fm)=∫m∈Δ​C(Fm,[Δmn​,Gm]).
entry.summary: Weâ€™d like to understand the following proposition, due (as near as I can tell) to Quillen in Homotopical Algebra:

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
Youâ€™ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyllâ€™s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: Youâ€™ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
